1.  I guess I should have been an engineer, not a teacher.  O well.  (But I do like what I do.)
2.  I wonder
1) how the breakdown between Education in STEM vs. Humanities would look like... probably not much difference in public education, but maybe more in private / charter educational facilities?
2) how much longer will our society continue to consider teaching its next generation not as worthy a career as other work?
3.  I think that this graph reinforces the attitudes towards teaching & teachers that currently exist in our society.

name: Alexander
comment info: STEM jobs have higher wages than Humanities and English majors do. I think this wage gap has to do with the fact that there is a higher demand for STEM than English, for example, because we as a society are making further advancements in the field than other areas of study. The graph presents an important factor: the monetary value of teachers is much lower than other majors. It also omits many key factors, such as the amount time spent at a job and other necessary pieces of info, which is peculiar because this graph is supposed to show the future of careers. I can infer that the author wants the audience to focus on the salaries of these jobs, even though it completely defies the purpose of job, which is to do something that you feel can help contribute to the world. The author shines a light on a society obsessed with the monetary value of a job, instead of the job itself.

name: dylan lougee
comment info: I noticed that most jobs that jobs that are about research earn more than jobs about philosophy or teaching even though you have to study for the same period of time for each job. I also noticed the higher paying the job is the wider range the dark blue range has (25%-50%). This makes me ask  what or who decides how much each job is payed. Why is there such a large range in the amount of money a person makes in each field why do certain people make less than others for the same job. This graph shows that even if you get a job with a lower minimum wage you can still make as much as a job that pays its average worker much more. It also shows jobs that you have to work harder for and go to school longer for can still make you less money.

name: Thomas Frisoli
comment info:
I notice that some of the more specific jobs that you have to be more qualified for get paid a lot more. The same percentile for Education earns about two million less the the same percentile for Chemical engineering. 

I wonder if the same jobs will continue to take a lot of money of if maybe some will drop when we don't need them as much. I also wonder what the same jobs salaries will be in ten years.

In this graph there showing average salaries and what jobs make more money than others.

name: Hailey
comment info: From looking at this graph I notice that jobs relating to STEM often get paid more. The sciences are often the most highly paid jobs. There are a variety of jobs that all make a lot of money, but most of the money is in science or technology jobs. I wonder how they got these estimations. I also am curious to know what jobs people with each of these degrees have. The graph is showing that we probably need more science and technology majors.

name: Katherine
comment info: From viewing this graph I notice how there is such a large variety in job options. There are many different possible roads you can go down. It also shows that jobs in STEM make a large amount of money compared to most other careers. I wonder how it is decided who makes the most or least money in individual career paths. The pay ranges vastly within the jobs. I also wonder what degrees they had to get or what courses they had to complete to be able to qualify and achieve these jobs. I could probably answer these questions by simply doing some research on the topics. This graph is showing predicted estimations on the amount of money a particular career might earn a person in their lifetime, depending on what percentile they are in.

name: Mary
comment info: After looking closely at the graph, I noticed that the jobs in education, social work, and humanities have the lowest earnings. Whereas, engineering is significantly higher. I wonder why engineering jobs like electrical engineering and chemical engineering earn so much money compared to other jobs. Over all, I think this graph successfully showed the estimated range of career earnings for college graduates in several different majors.

name: Rebecca Chase
comment info: IN this graph, I notice that STEM jobs appear to have the highest incomes. The average lifetime earnings of someone who majors in engineering, computer sciences, math, etc.  are much higher than those of someone who  majors in English, humanities, or the liberal arts. I wonder how the incomes differ for people of different genders, races, etc. Because the graph includes the average income for everyone in each field, there is no insight into how much specific groups of people are earning. I am also curious as to how counting people with even higher levels of education would effect the graph.

name: Maddie
comment info: While looking at the graph, I noticed that a lot of the higher paying jobs were STEM jobs. I expected these jobs to be higher paying because they are very needed and useful today. I was strange to me that an English teacher gets paid more than a psychologist. I wonder how much these jobs used to be payed and what used to be the highest paying job. I don't think that it was the same 20 years ago.

name: Matthew Brown
comment info: I noticed while looking at this graph that most of the more commonly seen professions and jobs are seen with the lower earnings. The careers that are more rare to us are the ones that have a higher paycheck. This makes sense because the more common a job is, the more people there are doing it, and the less money they get paid. With higher paid jobs, there are less people in the field of business, the more money each worker makes. Something that I wonder is if, overtime, some jobs will become more popular, and if the earnings from different jobs will level out. I also wonder what this would be like in the future, if it will increase in income or decrease. Same for in the past, what was it like back then?

name: Piper Hall
comment info: I've noticed that the STEM jobs earn someone much more money than someone working in more social and artistic jobs. It's sad that a job in education doesn't earn more money, since they are the ones teaching those who work in STEM. Of course, I wonder how the college you attend affects how much money you make. Additionally, what if someone doesn't go to college? how much money would they make? Also I wonder if gender affects how much money made in each job because women still make less money than men in most jobs.

name: Jacob
comment info: I noticed that more technological jobs usually get paid the most amount of money. Is there anything that can affect the way people get paid? Are there any factors in these jobs that can stimulate different amounts of money people earn?

name: steve
comment info: What factor is responsible for certain degrees have a broader spectrum of percentile earnings than others? Why is the spectrum of the amount of money a college graduate with a major in economics so spaced out, while Nursing and other humanities have a restricted spectrum?

name: Quatz T Smoony
comment info: STEM jobs typically seem to be higher, like Chemical and Electrical engineering and computer science. Though the medians of the incomes gradually increase, the minimum and maximum is not always consistent. For instance, criminal justice has a higher minimum than Liberal Arts and Psychology, but the minimum of criminal justice is still lower and comes before the other two jobs.

name: flluffybunny23
comment info: As I look at the graph, I wonder what the wages are for different genders and races. While women typically make less then men, I wonder how this differs throughout the different jobs. I also am curious how it differs with different races and the various types of work.

replies.comment info: I agree with your astute statement. Congratulations!

name: Sam Lucis
comment info: This doesn't account for the connection between going to grad school and getting higher paying jobs.

name: Danielle
comment info: All the career earnings for college graduates are all around 3-4 million, and sciences and maths seem to be on the high demand. I wonder why chemical engineering seems to be in more demand than other engineering fields. I could find these answer when doing a little bit of research. The jobs that are in high demand for new technology to be produced seem to have a higher earning than those of teaching degrees. The story of this graph shows that jobs that will advance our society will be in high demand

name: Keely
comment info: why didn't you answer these questions? - Where do these data come from? Was it from a survey or a statistical model? If a survey, who was included and what questions were asked? How was “projected career earnings” calculated?

name: Claire Mahaffey
comment info: By observing this graph, one may have a few keen observations. The visual portrays the projected career earnings, as opposed to yearly wages and the information has been updated recently. The fields are listed in increasing median earnings, ranging from Education to Chemical Engineering. However, while the median earnings increase as the graph continues, the top and bottom percentiles do not increase or decrease uniformly. One may wonder why this inconsistency occurs, however that information requires researching each field individually to find the reason for the deviation. Furthermore, this graph infers the projected career earnings, but cannot be expected to hold entirely true. It is impossible to predict the future with total accuracy, and therefore the information provided should not dictate any important decisions.

name: Jonathan
comment info: The graph objectively depicts the approximate lifetime earnings of various vocations within different fields of study. A median, as well as a 10th, 25th, 75th, and 90th percentile, are plotted on the graph as they locate and quantize the range of projected salaries that populations within each field receive. The varying majors located on the left display a common trend, in that the majors related to science and economy gravitate towards the higher end of the spectrum while other jobs, namely government paid vocations, lean towards the lower end. There remains an outlier on the last major, chemical engineering, as their median as well as their range are noticeably higher than all other majors. As the title states how these earnings are for college graduates, it can be inferred that the graph is intended for students looking for different types of jobs and depicts the monetary incentive for each career type. Nonetheless, a large amount of factors are omitted within this graph as certain components, such as what amount of time constitutes a career, are never specified. This fallacy impedes the overall credibility of the graph and detracts from the data presented to the reader.

name: Savi S
comment info: Based off the graph, the same amount of college education can result in differences of salaries across majors. The median numbers increases as the list goes down and they usually lean towards the left of the blue. The higher earning figures tend to be in the S.T.E.M. field as compared to the others. Due to the growing demand of progress, those careers are often paid larger amounts for their work. The top earning S.T.E.M. majors seem to have more competition compared to wider fields such as philosophy and are harder to get a job in than the rest. Even though those fields are going to be useful in the future, we as a society need to appreciate other fields like Education and Social more. Those fields are just as important in lending a hand in progressing our society and they deserve a higher salary than they are getting currently. The graph does not tell the whole story, factors such as location, economy, if its a government or company job, and degree of difficulty effects how much a person makes during a career. The graph is likely to change in the future because of the changing economy we have today. If a majority in College chose Chemical Engineering due to this graph, the career earnings would go down drastically due to a drop in competition. I would not recommend this graph for choosing a career because of the factors that do not go into it.

name: Bill nye
comment info: Some things I notice are from the top to the bottom of the graph the median wages increase. I see that the top half are mostly areas of studies that may be paid for by the government such as education or criminal justice. Therefore, we can imply that government salaries tend to be lower than science majors such as chemical engineering or computer science, which are located near the lower part of the graph with higher median ranges. Because the graph shows different career paths, their main audience are incoming teens who have to decide their majors for college. In the end, based on this graph students may choose one of these careers solely on money.  However, I wonder if this information is completely accurate for students in fours years who may have to decide their fields of study now. Not only that but there are many other factors that contribute to deciding one's field of study. Therefore, I don't think this graph is beneficial as one piece of evidence for jobs or career paths solely based on over generalized wages which in the end may end up changing overtime.

name: Katie Parker
comment info: Douglas Webber in his “The Lifetime Earnings Premia of Different Majors” analyzes projected career income from solely an economical standpoint. Looking at the graph, I noticed that the bottom half of the careers focus mostly on the STEM subjects. The careers that earn a lesser amount money appear to be geared more towards social-oriented subjects, such as philosophy and education. The white dashes on the bars are the median earnings, and the darker shades of blue are the points nearest to the median. It is questionable if this graph is really proportional, as well as if the graph is accurate. I am unaware of where the author received his information, causing me to feel quite skeptical of the graph. I am curious as to how many incomes were utilized in order to create this bar graph and if taxes were included or removed from the overall earnings. This graph could be indicating how as a society, we have drifted away from more social careers in favor of technology.

name: Riley McQuay
comment info: According to the New York Times Graph, the more time that needs to be invested in a field of work, the income is typically increased. The graph shows a wide array of studies that can range from Education to Chemical Engineering, both of which need different amounts of time to major in. The graph is titled “Projected Career Earnings for College Graduates in…” and was updated in 2017 by Douglas A. Webber; Webber’s intended audience was most likely High School Graduates who had set ambitious goals for college and did not know what to major in. With this graph, high school graduates can see the averages of what each career has financially which would give the student more insight on what they want to pursue. Additionally, this graph shows the highest and lowest amount of earnings per career (from $1 million to $6 million) and typically the STEM-based majors tend to attract more college students.

name: Jacob Nguyen
comment info: The general trend of the graph seems to reflect that STEM-based career paths tend to result in higher projected career earnings than language-based or social science-based careers. This trend implies that people do not value the language and social-based careers enough even though I believe they do play a significant role in the infrastructure of society and the development of citizens’ minds. Also, while the median career earning does increase from the top to bottom of the graph, the range between the 10th and 90th percentiles also generally increases. The greater dispersion of career earnings may be a result of many people wanting to go into higher paying careers. Greater competition would be generated, causing a wider spectrum in the amount of money people in the same career path can earn. Thus, job availability should be taken into consideration along with the projected earnings. It is not wise to choose a career path based solely on the information shown by this graph because it is lacking the consideration of factors without a monetary incentive, such as satisfaction and passion—it is important for people to love their careers. I wonder how the data on this graph was collected and whether it only reflects the projected earnings for only a certain group of college graduates in society or whether it reflects all college graduates. I am curious to know if factors such as the university someone attends or their race/ethnicity can alter what the graph currently displays.

name: Brittney East
comment info: I noticed that as the careers become more related to fields in STEM, the median earnings increase. While I agree to some extent that the graph portrays a realistic visual of average career earnings, I believe that it has failed to take into account other factors beside the field of the career. Jobs like computer science and chemical engineer are becoming more popular amongst college students, which might make the supply for these jobs less demanding. With more people applying for similar positions, companies can pay workers lower salaries. Another factor, besides supply and demand, is passion. What the graph fails to consider is that some college students choose a certain career path out of passion or love for a subject. By categorizing the careers based on their earnings, Webber is associating careers with the amount of money that is earned. I agree that money should factor into considering a career, but it should not be the sole factor in determining a certain path.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: I agree with your thoughts on how Webber leaves on important factors in how students make their decisions on which careers to follow. I had not really thought about what you had said about how with increasing popularity of certain STEM careers, eventually wages for these jobs may greatly decrease due to the large amount of people in that industry. Career incomes could change greatly in the future as we have no way to tell what will happen to certain jobs and the income they make. While a career may be in high demand right now, and therefore could have a high income, in the future the demand may die down and people might earn much less in that career, or the other way around. Also, I think passion is something extremely important in deciding which career as student should follow, and by not considering this in his graph, students may choose careers simply due to high earnings rather than what they would enjoy doing for the rest of their lives.

name: P. L. Dodd
comment info: As indicated by the graph, the median wage for different careers fields increases as the graph progresses from top to bottom. In addition, most of the careers with median wages of $3 million or higher are STEM based, while careers with median wages that fall below $3M are based primarily on sociology, language, history, or the arts. I wonder if such discrepancy between career types is due to a higher demand for workers in scientific and mathematical fields, than others that fall outside of STEM. Although there are exceptions to this rule, the general pattern of the graph supports the idea that the economy favors STEM based careers. In my opinion, the graph seems to advise college students deciding on a major to enter these fields, using solely money as a motivation. I personally disagree with the notion that one should reconsider their major based on earnings alone because these statistics are subject to change and if one has no business in chemical engineering, then they should not enter such a career they are not adept at, nor take interest, in for the pay. Though I concede that sufficient salary is important as well as job availability, they should not be the only criteria in deciding a major, and thus the graph should be used as a supplement in a decision, not the sole deciding factor.

replies.name: H
replies.comment info: It is interesting that you find the graph is advising students on their majors solely based on the various salaries, rather than merely providing another source for their decisions. While I agree that students should not use this graph as their only criteria for deciding their major, the graph does not necessarily suggest that this is the only evidence for students, as you suggested. However, I completely agree in your understanding that the graph below $3 million lacks a strong STEM based presence among the majors, while above $3 million is the opposite. This “discrepancy,” as you call it, is very interesting as more people may be pushed towards fields with higher salaries regardless of other factors, that are not mentioned in the graph. Considering all majors are focused in different areas of human knowledge (ex. History, Math, Science, English), some might think that the gap between Education and Chemical Engineering would not be so far apart on the graph due to their individual importance.

name: Bree Q.
comment info:
By observing the graphs, I have noticed that the majority of the STEM majors are given higher wages. Meanwhile, the more socially-related fields earn less. The order of the graph may be affected by various reasons, such as the demand for jobs and the budget of employers.
I was surprised that chemical engineering earned the most. I believed that people in such a field would earn less since the engineering major is often impacted in college. The placement of each career could heavily influence a person in deciding what they would want to pursue. And so, I disagree with the placement of education. Education is the foundation of the other careers listed. Without it, I believe it would be impossible to excel in any of those fields listed. I am skeptical of this graph because it could become skewed by possible changes in the economy or an increase in the amount of people who are passionate in a specific career. I wonder how heavily the graph will impact the choices of students, and how it will change over time.

name: Ava
comment info: By observing the graph, I notice that average career earnings largely vary based on the career, as chemical engineering has a much higher wage than education.  It is interesting that jobs based on the social sciences generally have lower earnings than those involving science and math.  Though it may be true that science-based careers are more difficult and require more schooling, many are just as important as jobs such as education that make significantly less money.  If it were not for those who work in this field, other careers with higher earnings would not have dependable employees who could fulfill and understand their duties. Each career greatly impacts the others and have a great effects on the world as a whole, making the vast difference in earnings unfitting.

name: Amir
comment info: Based off of what I see in the graph, it shows the lifetime salaries for several different jobs. I notice the jobs at the top of the graph have a smaller range in the amount of money that can be made possibly because they are mostly jobs that are paid by the government. I also notice that many of the jobs in the second half of the graph are related to science and technology. From my understanding, most of the jobs shown on the graph are accepted as “good jobs” but the difference between the highest and lowest salary is very large. The graph shows how little or how much money one can earn from getting a college education.

name: Person
comment info: As I was observing these graphs I noticed that between the 10th and 25th percentile, even a chemical engineer can make as much as the average person studying psychology. I believe the reason for this falls under supply and demand. Even though Chemical Engineering can be considered as a much more difficult job than Psychology, it all depends on if the place where they live really needs a Psychologist or a Chemical Engineer. So for this reason, when looking at the 75th to 90th percentile I see that the Chemical Engineer can make 5 or 6 times more than a Psychologist not because it might be a more difficult job, but because there is a plethora of psychologists, and a scarce amount of Chemical Engineers. With the idea of supply and demand comes the fact that companies or businesses rely more on efficiency to meet the demand. This means that all workers have an expiration date and when they reach the peak of their productivity, they could easily be replaced by others willing to work harder and more efficiently.

name: Anthony Paris
comment info: This graph argues for which careers college students should follow in order to earn the most money over their lifetime. Douglas Webber analyzes the benefits of different careers from an economic standpoint, demonstrating which career college graduates can ultimately gain the most wealth from. Webber contends that money should be the greatest influence in one’s career choice through his indirect support of students choosing careers which will give them the greatest wealth over factors such as passion or interest. His graph may also give inaccurate results as he is simply speculating over the amount of money people could make in their lifetime in a career, as demand could rise or fall, leading to an increase of decrease in income made. He also demonstrates a bias by his favoring of mainly STEM majors as careers with the highest earnings. Surely, there are many other careers which earn large sums of money and are not STEM, and by not including these majors, he attempts to persuade the observer to choose STEM careers in order earn the most wealth.

name: Chayush
comment info: The graph displayed depicts the career earnings for college graduates in specific areas of study. Firstly, the graph has two colors, light blue and dark blue, the dark blue representing the average earnings, and the light blue to represent the outliers, or the highest and lowest, in the pay scale. Another observation is that the careers that live in the areas of math and science tend to make more money over time than the careers based in the areas of literature, art, and critical thinking. This graph, while giving a good prediction of the earning, is flawed. It does not take into account the different factors that affect the earnings in some careers such as: level of education, working environment, passion for that field, inflation over time, the effect of government control over some careers like education, or criminal justice, and it does not take into account the different jobs that can be obtained with these different careers. While this graph gives a general overview of the earnings that can be obtained when following certain areas of study, it is not a good reference to choose a future career.

name: diane
comment info: By analyzing the graph for a while, I understood that this graph was relating the percentiles college graduates are in in respect to their majors. I noticed that majority of the STEM related majors are given higher wages when compared to those with theoretical and literature based majors, which could be concerning because it also showed that education was one of the most low paid majors; everyone who has high wages were highly impacted by the education that they receive. All in all, I believe that Education should be one of the most rewarding in money. However, I am skeptical of this graph because the amount of people who are passionate within a field could change and the amount of money that goes into a certain field can be skewed over time because of it; there is also a high possibility that some of these majors will cease to exist in the future.

name: Dana Lee
comment info: The graph represents the projected career earnings for college graduates based on their major. Although, the graph appears to be a credible source, the sheer fact that the data is a “projection” implies that it could be incredibly inaccurate. The demand and funding for specific career options is constantly fluctuating and especially in the event of a severe economic crisis, specific earnings could plummet or skyrocket unexpectedly. Additionally, the graph can be misleading in the fact that the lowest and highest 10 percent of the projected career earnings are left off the chart. Therefore, if someone enters in the field expecting to make a certain amount, they may be unhappily surprised to realize they are in the lowest percentile and earning severely less than expected. Furthermore, low projections may discourage students from majoring in a field that may be best suited for them, and lose the opportunity to thrive at a job they excel at. I wonder what the reach of this graph is, and whether or not it will impact the decision of college students.

name: Misha
comment info: As I read the graph, I notice the placement of the career paths as well as the differences in amounts each career earns. For instance, Chemical Engineering graduates can earn up to almost 6 million dollars if successful where to Education graduates can earn up to about 3 million dollars. Different factors play into the wide range of earnings. Because most education and criminal justice majors tend to work for the government, earnings can be less compared to a computer science major who works for a company with a larger budget. The vast difference in earnings implies what careers are more popular in today’s society as well as possibly persuading future graduate students to pick their majors according to earnings. However, the credibility of the graph is questioned as “projected career earnings” can change in the future because of the unknown problems that can occur. Because of this, I wonder if future graduates do rely on such graphs when choosing the major they wish to study.

name: Noora Borja
comment info: After analyzing the graph, I have noticed that the jobs that are deeply rooted in science make a huge amount of money compared to the jobs that are more social and English related. As someone who is looking to major in psychology, I found it disheartening to find that it made a significant amount less than other majors. However, I hope that people will use the graph only for reference and not base their decisions for college on it. Passion is one of the most important factors in finding a major that it is a good fit for you. If I based my major off of how much money I could possibly make I would choose Chemical engineering, a major I have no interest in pursuing. I also found it odd that education, the basis of all of the majors listed makes the least amount of money.

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: I agree that the projections in the graph suggest that typically STEM based majors provide higher career earnings on average than that of others. However, there is still a high level of overlap between even the highest earning major and the lowest. Therefore, it is still possible to earn more with a philosophy major rather than a chemistry major even though it may not be expected. Furthermore, I agree that choosing a major based on passion and interest rather that income is very important. A field of study that one enjoys is much more likely to lead to a better job opportunity than one that is not best suited for that person’s talents or characteristics.

name: Callie Thomas
comment info: I don’t like how the criminal justice section highest paying percentiles are not paid as much as the other important career options high paying percentiles. I feel criminal justice studies take a lot more school and time compared to other paths, to be able to graduate efficiently and should have a higher paid or at least roughly the same percentile then a lot of careers. Criminal justice should be looked at as an important, very necessary job and showing how even their highest paid percentiles are still lower than most will discourage people from choosing that path as a career. There is an argument within this graph, it shows the difference in salary between the more common jobs versus the more unique. Education is the lowest paid job and chemical engineering is the highest. The difference of salary is extensive showing that education is not nearly as important as chemical engineering. A really good education is needed to be able to be successful in chemical engineering. Every career starts with education and their percentile is low that the career path of education will be looked at as inferior to something like chemical engineering. This is a problem in society as less people will go into the education path but more will expect an adequate education.

name: Isdenil
comment info: I think this graph shows peoples jobs and how much money they make in a lifetime. The job i'm interested is accounting and it seems interesting the earnings through the years.

name: Sophia ;)
comment info: I notice that the earnings of each career gradually increase the lower they are. These higher paying careers tend to be STEM-related and more practical than those located in the upper region of the graph. This may imply that, because these careers are more practical, they are in higher demand which is why they get paid more. I wonder why it is that the bars in the lower portion are larger and why the lengths of the darker blue vary among each career. This variation may be explained by the labels shown at the top and bottom of the graph; the lowest and highest percentiles indicate that the fields presented at the bottom have a wider range of earnings. The story this graph is telling is that there is an imbalance of pay among the different careers, despite most of them being almost equally important. For example, education is exceedingly necessary for the progression of our society and ensuring that the careers like those located towards the bottom are pursued and reached.

name: Shaun H.
comment info: According to the graph, careers that fall into the S.T.E.M. category tend to receive higher earnings than the other listed careers. This trend is likely caused by the fact that these careers are greatly demanded as of now. Society wants to progress rapidly and it needs many people in S.T.E.M. careers in order to accomplish this. While society’s progression may justify the large salaries of S.T.E.M. careers, it does not justify the low salaries of those who graduate with a major in education and in criminal justice. People who have careers in education are highly responsible for progressing society as well, since they educate future generations. As a result, they deserve to have higher salaries than the graph indicates. Similarly, those who major in criminal justice are the people that ensure society remains ordered and safe. Without these justice workers, civilization would not be able to advance, so they also deserve higher wages than they receive at the moment. Because the government is usually responsible for paying the people in these careers, their low salaries indicate that the government is neglecting important workers that deserve higher pay.

name: abby :)
comment info: I noticed that majority of the STEM careers have higher earnings.  The demand, location, difficulty, and duration of a occupation can affect the amount of money earned.  I wonder how accurate the graph is because jobs are constantly changing, along with their salaries.  The graphs predicts the future of a career, so it can only be an estimate based off past patterns.  I wonder how long a career must be according to the graph, because wages can increase based off how long an employee is working for a company.  The story the graph is telling is different occupations will earn different career salaries.  The graph implies that each college graduate has an equal education in their field, thus indicating that starting off equally does not mean that all career earnings will be financially equivalent in the long run.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: I think it is interesting that you noticed how the prediction in the graph may not be accurate. Often times, people take data from credible news sources (such as this one) as undoubtedly accurate. However, being skeptical indicates that someone has the capacity to have a conversation with what they are reading. Additionally, your observation is important because students may pursue these careers thinking that they will receive higher pay in the future, but in the future when they secure a job in that field, they may find that they do not receive the salary they thought they would get. Your idea that the graph implies that each college graduate has a equal education is significant as well. If everyone has to go through a similar educational process, one would assume that their hard work would pay off in the future equally. But it is evident in the graph that this is not the case.

name: Helia Aval
comment info:
By observing the graph, I noticed that it is based off various college majors and their earnings. However, as you go further down the list of majors, many high-earning majors become more STEM-based. This may be due to various factors such as higher or lower demand for jobs and the budgets of employers.
I wonder how this graph, or the ideas conveyed by it, will affect incoming college students as they pick their majors and also wonder how much the graph will change over time. If the majority of college students becomes Chemical Engineering majors, will that lower the demand and therefore the earnings in that field? If less students pursue Education due to its low earnings, as of 2017, will that provoke higher earnings in the future?
The story this graph is telling me is that, in 2017, scientific and technological majors seem to be earning more money in their fields while other majors seem to be earning less while also highlighting the increased focus on STEM-based fields as more people may be inclined to pursue those jobs

name: Bob
comment info: The graph contends that higher paying jobs are typically associated with STEM majors. It utilizes a comparison between the medians of projected career earnings in different fields. However, the graph is not omniscient. It attempts to predict wages years into the future, which can be highly inaccurate. For example, the economics field is set as the second greatest money earner, yet if there were a horrific stock market collapse tomorrow, the economics would quickly fall down the ranks of top paying jobs. The graph is intended as a guide for students deciding on their major, yet it leaves itself vulnerable to unforeseen changes years in the future. Students should not use the graph as their sole source of advice when it comes to career choice, especially since they will leave college jobless and in desperate need of a way to pay off their debt. However, the graph does aid in revealing the current state of careers since it is based on recently updated information. It also has a more expansive amount of data available to viewers to inform them of the current job climate. It does have its uses, but it should not be viewed as the law of the land.

name: shaelynn matz
comment info: I notice that chemical engineering majors make a significantly larger amount of money than any other major. I notice the median is always slanted towards the lower side of the graph (the left side) meaning there is a lot more people who earn less than average money in that career than people who make more than average money. I wonder to what year the chart is projected towards. I wonder what the total earnings constitutes… 40 years of work? 50? I notice two different shades of blue- probably showcasing the extremes. Most of the higher-earning career majors are STEM majors. This graph may also not be accurate in the future. Jobs are constantly growing and declining to suit the needs of society. Society’s needs often differ and flux as it progresses. For example, children that are a result of a baby boom are growing older and will need more hospital care, hence creating the need for more nurses, creating a high demand which generates higher salaries for nurses and doctors- higher than possibly could have been projected. The story this graph is telling is that in the future, STEM majors will generally be more needed (and rarer) than other common majors.

name: Neal Patel
comment info: The overall career earnings projections in the chart reflect a deeply rooted mentality in today’s American society. We have the mentality of looking towards STEM majors to fix our issues at hand or to enhance our lives. For the most part, we are disregarding the types of jobs that will help us address issues in our society as a whole. For example, career choices of education, social work, or philosophy are projected to earn much less than careers such as chemical, or electrical engineering. This illustrates a very prevalent issue. We don’t want to be examined or have our communities changed but rather we support industries that serve to enhance our day to day lives. New technology products help individuals better their lives whereas careers that produce thought and incite understanding have much less appeal to our increasingly materialistic world. Non-STEM careers remain relatively unattractive to the current society because we don’t want to necessarily take the time or energy to think about our society.

replies.name: M

Issues on race and equality has been around for centuries and still is not being fully addressed currently. Certain careers, such as philosophy and education, can assist in improving our society socially as it brings about different ideas on approaching difficult matters. Though STEM majors seems to be more appealing with the impression of the high amounts of earnings, careers that follow more of a social and moral appeal is equally as important. This questions the goal of this chart on whether it creates more of an appeal towards STEM careers and that non-STEM careers are not crucial in our technology savvy world.

name: Kyla C
comment info:
One of my first observations was that the professions are ordered by median in increasing order. I also observe that there is considerable variation within each profession and think that perhaps there is less (though still significant) variation between the professions. As a college student studying math and humanities, I found it comforting to observe that there is a lot of overlap - it might be less likely, but a philosophy major sometimes earns more than an economics major. 

I notice that nursing is far down (higher lifetime earnings) and that surprises me. I'd like to know more about who was counted as a nursing major and whether those students trained solely to be nurses or whether perhaps some were pre-med and went on to be doctors.

That brings me to my biggest point: thinking in terms of majors can be deceptive. English majors can become chemistry PhDs. Psychology majors can join PR firms. I've read that kids from wealthier backgrounds often have more freedom to do "riskier" humanities majors - some of them then end up in law or finance. Overall, I think this graph might be trying to tell a story about how choice of major can affect lifetime earnings, but I think there is a lot not said that my fellow students should consider. We need to remember that major does not dictate career path, and thus the graph does not necessarily reflect how much people actually working in the areas they majored in earn.

replies.name: K
replies.comment info:
Individuals who acquire a degree in STEM are paid more than others because of the fact that there are less people who are willing to work in fields of science. In most colleges Criminal Justice is one of the most heavily impacted majors. For instance, according to CSUs, criminal justice is one of the undergraduates programs that is impacted in 11 of the Cal State campuses. So for example, if there are 100,000 people looking for a jobs who have a degree in criminal justice, but there are only 50,000 jobs available, they will most likely be willing to have lower pay due to the scarcity in jobs; however in contrast, there are 20,000 jobs that require  an individual with a degree in chemical engineering, but only 10,000 individuals have a degree in chemical engineering. These individuals are evidently more qualified and have the advantage of determining the amount of salary they are paid. The difference in the amount of pay between one who has a degree in science opposed to an individual who doesn't  is mainly due to the scarcity in jobs and opportunities.
Link below lists the impacted majors in CSUs:
https://www.calstate.edu/sas/documents/ImpactedProgramsMatrix.pdf

name: Nirmal Agnihotri
comment info: The New York Times graph projecting the career earnings of different college majors is very much targeted toward a high school audience. In other words, the teens of America who will soon make the jump to college and subsequently decide their career, finally having to answer the most annoying question they have been asked their entire lives: “What do you want to be when you grow up?” However, the graph is certainly not the end all be all. In fact, it should not even play the most significant role when deciding a college major. There are numerous other factors to consider that play a role. Of course there are a person’s interests, but there are also more concrete factors. For example, there is job growth. Chemical engineering, which according to the graph seems he most enticing, has a much slower growth than say computer science and thus is not nearly as secure. In addition, work hours st be considered. The biggest reason education earns the least is due to the fact that it is a government job. Yet, government jobs have far lower hours compared to private sector jobs and may thus be more enticing than it seems when glancing at this graph. America’s youth must realize that the nuances of careers are increasingly important as competition is rising in the new global economy. The future is daunting, but America’s youth can surely prepare.

name: Christian Roman

name: Moderator Erica
comment info:
Thanks to all teachers and students who responded to our graph on the earning power of college graduates by major.  How much you make in a career isn’t the only criteria for selecting a major, but did this graph change your thinking about your college major and future career?

Lots of questions came up from this graph.  You asked how the majors were selected, how projected earnings were calculated, and how many years is considered a lifetime.  You wondered about what the 10th, 25th, 75th, and 90th percentile means and why the blue segments are of different lengths.  But, most frequently, you noticed that education majors made less than STEM majors.  As O'BryantGirlNamedFallon from Boston wrote, “Well, to me it seems like the teachers, who shape the future of our children, are not getting the money they deserve. I wonder, why should the teachers who help all these people reach their dreams, why should they get the lowest pay?” 

Since we continue to post responses, is there more that you notice?  More that you wonder?  Talk to your classmates and read the moderators’ responses. Maybe something they say will lead to more things you notice, wonder, and conjecture. 

Check back on Thursday, January 11 to learn more about this graph. We hope to see you again next month on Tuesday, February 13 for our next "What's Going On In This Graph?"   Signing off now -- Sharon in Boston and Erica in Pittsburgh. See you in February for our special Valentine’s Day graph!

I noticed that the economics and nursing field is skewed to the right much more than some of the STEM fields such as physics and biological sciences. The fact that the economics and nursing fields earn a higher lifetime earning than these other STEM fields is surprising. The general trend of this graph is that STEM fields have a higher pay. This makes me wonder, then, how many people actually achieve this profession. How many graduated with a high degree, and how many graduated from a prestigious university? If there are many educators living off a lower pay, and yet a few computer engineers making twice their lifetime earnings, it could be a danger to the distribution of wealth, the welfare of the classes, and the future of the next generations. 1. What Do You Notice?
I notice that a career in chemical engineering gives the most money, while a career gives the least money over a whole career.
2. What's going on in this graph?

3. What do you wonder?
I wonder if this graph shows a proportional or linear relationship.

replies.comment info:
Hi, Timothy Rutler!  Love that you followed What do you notice?,  What do you wonder?, and What's going on in this graph?

This graph is a variation of a boxplot.  (You can search boxplot online to read more.)  For boxplots, the percentiles (10th, 25th, 50th (Median), 75th, and 90th) show you what percentage of earnings values are below this value.  For example, for Criminal Justice, 75% of graduates have career earnings less than about $2,900,000.  Can you interpret the other percentiles?  And, how do the percentiles compare from major to major?
